column1: Neuruppin (German: [nɔʏ.ʁʊ.ˈpiːn] (listen)) is a town in Brandenburg
column3: the administrative seat of Ostprignitz-Ruppin district. It is the birthplace of the novelist Theodor Fontane (1819–1898) and therefore also referred to as Fontanestadt. A garrison town since 1688 and largely rebuilt in a Neoclassical style after a devastating fire in 1787
column4: Neuruppin has the reputation of being "the most Prussian of all Prussian towns".

column1: The town is located on the shore of the Ruppiner See
column2: a lake traversed by the Rhin river
column3: about 60 km (37 mi) northwest of Berlin. In the north
column4: the hilly landscape of Ruppin Switzerland stretches up to the Rheinsberg Lake Region and the border with Mecklenburg-Vorpommern. It is part of the Stechlin-Ruppiner Land Nature Park.

column2: Neuruppin today is one of Germany's largest municipalities by area.

column5: Neuruppin on the western shore of the lake was established by the Lords of Lindow-Ruppin. First mentioned in a 1238 deed
column6: it became the first establishment of the Dominican Order between the Elbe and Oder rivers

Neuruppin received town privileges on 9 March 1256; town walls were erected and completed until the 15th century.

column1: In 1524 Ruppin Land was finally seized as a reverted fief by the Hohenzollern Elector Joachim I Nestor of Brandenburg. The monastery was secularised in the course of the Reformation and its premises ceded to the Neuruppin citizens. The town was ravaged by the Thirty Years' War
column2: from about 1685 French Huguenot refugees settled here. In 1688 Neuruppin became a Brandenburg-Prussian garrison town.

column1: After a disastrous fire in 1787 the Neo-Classicism of the rebuilt town's buildings characterise its townscape to the present day. It remained a garrison town until the late 20th century
column2: since Soviet (resp. Russian) troops were stationed here until 1993; during this time there were as many Soviet soldiers as inhabitants in Neuruppin.
